thread.title: Mixed martial artists set for big things after turning professional
thread.title_full: Mixed martial artists set for big things after turning professional

author: Sheldan Keay
title: Mixed martial artists set for big things after turning professional
text:
Mixed martial artists set for big things after turning professional Antonio Sheldon and Luckasz Pilch, from Rochdale, are to join coach Martin Stapleton in pro ranks Share Martin Stapleton, left, with Antonio Sheldon   
Two mixed martial artists from Full Contact Performance Centre in Rochdale are set for big things after turning professional. 
Antonio Sheldon and Luckasz Pilch have both had extremely impressive amateur careers training under Martin Stapleton, but they will now be joining him in the professional ranks. Luckasz Pilch 
Sheldon went 8-2 as an amateur, winning the FCC title and ICE FC British amateur title along the way. 
He also holds a purple belt in BJJ from the world renowned SBG gym, home to UFC superstar Conor McGregor. 
Sheldon’s last fight was shown on TV station Fightlife. 
Pilch recently earned his blue belt in BJJ, and picked up an amateur British title in 2016. 
The two fighters are the first from the extremely successful Castleton-based FCPC gym to turn professional, with a number of other impressive amateur fighters also training with the team. Martin Stapleton celebrates after winning the vacant BAMMA world lightweight championship in 2015 
It marks a busy few months for trainer Stapleton, who is also going from strength to strength in his own MMA career. 
He signed with Cage Warriors last month, with it now confirmed that he will face former Bellator MMA fighter Anthony Dizy in a 150-pound catchweight contest in Cage Warriors’ inaugural event at Indigo at The O2 on February 18. 
Tickets are from £20 at cagewarriors.com Like us on Facebook
